(vii) the child:
(A) requires personal care on 2 or more occasions between 10 pm and 6 am each day; and
(B) if under 6 months of age, is expected to require care as described in sub-subparagraph (A) at the age of 6 months.

Schedule 1 of the bill would extend the qualifications for carer payment to carers of profoundly disabled children, as we know. As currently drafted, part of the definition of `profoundly disabled' requires that a child's disability or condition include three or more of seven listed circumstances. Three of those circumstances are age related, and are as follows: the child is at least three and has urinary and faecal incontinence day and night; the child is at least two and cannot stand without support; the child is at least six months of age and requires personal care on two or more occasions between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. each day.

Since the introduction of the bill, extensive consultations have taken place with carer organisations on the impact of the measure. As a result of those consultations, it has been decided that these age related criteria should be extended to include not only a child who is under the age specified in a criterion, but also a child who has the care needs specified and who will not reach the relevant developmental milestone by the specified age. For example, in relation to a child standing without support, qualification would be extended to cover children who are under the age of two and unable to stand without support and who are expected to be unable to stand without support at the age of two.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Subparagraph 18A(2)(c)(iv), omit "urinary and faecal" (wherever occurring), substitute "urinary or faecal".

There was some discussion earlier today during the second reading debate about the concern the opposition had about the restrictive definition for children under the age of 16 years. In fact, the terminology was `profoundly disabled' rather than `severely handicapped', which is the definition for those who are over this age of 16 years.

The government did go on to define what `profoundly' means. It requires at least three of very specific criteria to be met. Frankly, each of them in themselves is pretty severe: the child must be tube fed; the child has a tracheotomy; the child requires a ventilator for at least eight hours a day; the child has urinary and faecal incontinence; the child cannot stand without support; the child's condition is terminal and palliative care has replaced active treatment; and the child requires personal care on at least two occasions between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. each day.

Each of those is pretty severe, but under this definition it is required that three of these be met before the carer is entitled to this allowance. I suppose that is why I said at the beginning that, while we welcomed the introduction of this payment, it was pretty paltry as far as it went. For a child to have three of those seven things—each of them, in my view, requiring fairly strenuous and all-encompassing care—is a bit too severe in the circumstances.

The amendments proposed by the government broaden those criteria in a very minor way and extend them a little. Under their definition, a child under three who is incontinent does not come within that criterion, but their request slightly broadens it by saying that if it is expected that the child will be incontinent after three—even though the child is under three at the moment—then that criterion is fulfilled. With regard to their request No. 3, under their definition, if you have to get up on at least two occasions between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. and the child is under six, you do not come within the last criterion. They have slightly broadened it so that, even if the child is under six at the time, if it is expected that once they are over six the carer will have to get up to them on at least two occasions between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. each day, then that criterion is fulfilled.

Of course, it is not sufficient that a child complies with one of those criteria: they must also comply with two others. So, having achieved one of the two matters set out in amendments 2 and 3, it does not necessarily mean that the person caring for them will qualify for this particular payment that is being provided by the government.

Our amendment to the government's request again is quite minute. In the fourth criterion, where it refers to the child having `urinary and faecal incontinence', the word `and' is replaced with `or', so in fact the child fulfils the criteria by being incontinent in only one of those regards rather than requiring them to be incontinent in regard to both aspects.
As I said, we are in agreement with the government's amendments, but we say that really does not take us very far.

talk.start.para: —I recognise that the opposition would like us to extend the definition of the profoundly disabled child—and we will come to their other amendments soon. I recognise that everybody would like to do more for people in these circumstances. However, this was, very deliberately, a carefully targeted measure to help those people who are in the greatest difficulty. It is for children who are dying or in appallingly difficult circumstances. It would never have crossed our minds that it would simply apply to children who have incontinence problems. The opposition's proposal that we are debating right now to remove the word `and' and replace it with `or' does not look very significant, but in fact it is. It means that children who are incontinent would in fact be eligible for this.
—It doesn't say that.

—That is how it reads, Senator. I do not know about your reading of it. Therefore, we cannot accept it. It would certainly extend payment, according to the advice I have now, to 1,000 customers, and it will cost $2 million.

speech.para: Quite apart from all that, it was not focused on children with urinary incontinence; it was for a multitude of problems of which a combination of urinary and faecal incontinence was just one of the important elements that help Centrelink to determine whether it is a profoundly disabled child. By removing the `and', you are doing more than you perhaps realise.

talk.start.para: —Your interpretation of our amendment is completely incorrect. Whoever has advised you has done so incorrectly because the amendment just changes one particular element of the requirement to say that a child has to have urinary or faecal incontinence. Even if they comply with one of those, it is still only one of the criteria: they still have to comply with two others before their carer can receive the allowance. So your statement that a child with urinary incontinence solely, or their carer, would be entitled to the payment is incorrect.

—If they are the exact words I used, I am sorry, you are right. Nevertheless, I stand by the advice I have been given, which is that your one little word change would mean that something like 1,000 people would be included who were not intended to be, at a cost of $2 million.

—I must say that I am quite fascinated to hear that estimate of how much it will cost. I would appreciate it if the minister could provide some details of that because it is difficult for me to imagine how they can get the statistics to support that. Maybe the minister could provide them.

speech.para: Essentially, the minister is saying that, for example, if a child has a tracheotomy and needs to be on a ventilator for at least eight hours a day and has urinary incontinence, then their carer should not be entitled to a payment. Minister, I think what you are saying is bizarre, that the carer is not entitled to the payment. It is so much less work for someone if the child they are caring for only has urinary incontinence and not faecal incontinence as well. I find that hard to understand, and I find it extraordinary that you, Senator Newman, would put that.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Neal to government request No 2 be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The question is that government request No. 2, as amended, and government request No. 3 be agreed to.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

(1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (line 13), before "continuous personal care" insert "constant supervision which is substantially greater than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability or".
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (after line 22), after subparagraph (c)(ii), insert:
(iia) the child needs substantially more assistance with feeding than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability;
(3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (line 33), at the end of paragraph (c), add:

; (viii) the child requires constant supervision, which is substantially greater than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability, to prevent injury to himself or herself, to another person or to property;
(ix) any other circumstance which, in the opinion of the Secretary, indicates that the child needs substantially more care or attention than a child of the same age who does not have a disability.

The effect of these amendments is again not overwhelming. They are intended to extend the criteria for those children under the age of 16 in some small way; that is, in relation to request No. 1, that the words `continuous personal care' be replaced by the words `constant supervision which is substantially greater than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability'.

As you can see, there may be a child who does require a great deal of supervision, but it may not be required continuously, at every moment. Essentially, what is required by the bill as it is presently drafted is for continuous personal care—for the carer to be in attendance at every moment. We believe that is too much and that the option we proposed is a more reasonable and, I suppose, middle ground in terms of the requirements.

Presently, under proposed subsection 18A(2), the child who is being cared for must satisfy at least three out of seven matters, and they are the matters I read out in the debate on the earlier amendment. Request No. 2 adds to the list a further circumstance in relation to children who require substantially greater assistance with feeding because of their disability. It does not change the fact that you are still required to satisfy three criteria, but it adds an eighth element to the list of matters—that is, that the children require substantially greater assistance with feeding as a result of their circumstances.

Request No. 3, again, slightly changes subsection 18A(2). It adds a further circumstance again—so that would be a ninth circumstance, of which three must be satisfied—and that is a general discretion to treat other circumstances as relevant. As we know, in drafting legislation, even though we may try to cover every possible criteria, there may in fact be some criteria that have not been thought of, that the minister or the department has not turned their minds to, that may actually have a very major impact on whether full-time care is required. This particular amendment allows such circumstances to be taken into account by the secretary.

talk.start.para: —These amendments are identical to the amendments that the Democrats would have moved, and, obviously, therefore we support them. As I detailed in my speech in the second reading debate, the Democrats believe that the definition of a profoundly disabled child needs to be broadened to meet the aims that the payment is designed for and, as such, these amendments insert additional circumstances in which a child will be seen as profoundly disabled for the purposes of the act.

—As I said during consideration of the previous amendment, I think that the opposition and the minor parties misunderstand the purpose that this was established for. In their efforts to help more people, they have expanded the eligibility criteria to a level that was never envisaged by the government at all.

speech.para: Honourable senator interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You understand that? Remember, if you had wanted to do this, you had 13 years in which to do it. I want to quickly put on the record just what the situation is. Your amendments would result in the measure losing its focus on assisting families in high-level caring situations. They would open the measures to a broad range of customers for whom it was not designed. Your three additional criteria will result in parents and carers of children with moderate disabilities entering the program, whereas the initiative is designed to capture families providing intensive or palliative care.

speech.para: The three criteria you are proposing will result in the payment being available to carers of children with moderate conditions, such as behavioural disorders including attention deficit disorder or oppositional defiant disorder. Children with these conditions, for example, may require substantial assistance with feeding, substantial supervision and extra attention in other functional areas such as communication, mobility, self-care skills, social and community skills. But the needs of children with disabilities such as these, when compared with the needs of children requiring intensive care for conditions such as dumping syndrome, are significantly less.

I want to give you an example of what this is really about. A nine-year-old child suffers from dumping syndrome—an extremely rare medical condition which results in her receiving insufficient nourishment from normal meals. She needs to be fed constantly, 24 hour a day, via a tube direct into her large intestine. She requires constant monitoring, as inconsistencies in feeding will result in unstable blood sugar levels and a risk of becoming comatose if untreated. The child is able to survive approximately 40 minutes without receiving formula. She also suffers from urinary incontinence and severe constipation, requiring daily enemas and other medications. The child also requires several other medications each day.

In their caring role, the parents need to check and record their daughter's blood sugar levels constantly, they need to load and calibrate the formula pumps and monitor the tube at all times to prevent kinks and blockages. The jejunostomy site must be cleaned and cared for. The child's baths need to be strongly supervised so as not to dislodge the tubes. The administration of the enema, and bathing and cleaning of the tubes and surrounding areas require both parents. Night-time care is monitored by an alarm attached to the formula dispensing pump as well as via a baby monitor. On any given night, the parents may be required to attend to the child on up to 12 occasions.

That is the kind of profoundly disabled person we are talking about. That is why I am concerned that you are diminishing a very important measure. You are jeopardising a very important measure by opening it up to families which do not have the same disabilities to contend with. The reason for my concern is that your amendments would add at least $36 million per year to the cost of the measure, compared with the current estimated cost of $1 million. You are potentially including something like 16,000 extra families because of your amendments—that is what you will do. Maybe you did not intend that, but that is the advice I have received.

talk.start.para: —Obviously the case described to us by Senator Newman was very disturbing, and we all have a lot of sympathy, but nothing I am proposing takes away from the care for that particular little girl or stops her from receiving a payment. All it does is extend it to other people who I believe, and the opposition believes—and many people in the community believe—are also in circumstances where they should be given the assistance of a carers payment.

speech.para: It is untrue to say that our amendments will mean that people with only a moderate disability will receive the payment. If you are describing someone who requires supervision at the level set out in our amendment and assistance with feeding but who must also comply with the criteria that presently exists, I do not believe that that is moderate. In my view, just one of the conditions set out here would certainly be in the community's mind much more than a moderate disability. How can you say that a child who has a terminal condition and who requires palliative care is only moderately disabled? I find that incomprehensible.

The minister cited figures earlier in this debate, and I asked her to provide the statistical back-up for those figures and the department was unable to give them. I will ask for them again, because it has become quite common practice for these sorts of figures to be quoted but very seldom do I ever get any real back-up. On the last occasion when I tracked down some information given like that, I was told eventually, after pursuing it for some time, that it was based on evidence provided by the department on an anecdotal basis and that they could not really disclose it because of privacy. In terms of anything that we could examine as members of the Senate who have a responsibility to examine information given, nothing was available to us. I ask you again for any statistical back-up to that proposition, because I have not found it in response to my previous requests yet.

talk.start.para: —I point out that the previous amendment for which I was asked to supply information was given to me this morning. Therefore, Senator Neal could hardly expect to have back-up information available for that amendment. I do have back-up information for what I have just said, and I think it would be important for you to take it in carefully.

speech.para: The costings that I have just given to you were based on the field testing data of nearly 400 child disability allowance tool stage 2 parent questionnaires. In preparing the costing, the department analysed the responses for those functional domains which correspond most closely to the additional criteria proposed in the opposition amendments. The assumption is that, for a child to be classified as requiring substantial additional assistance or supervision in a particular domain—for example, feeding—the parent would indicate that their child has a significant deficit in that domain.

In regard to your amendment that the child needs substantially more assistance with feeding than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability, 35 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child was at least one descriptor behind in self-care skills, including feeding and meal time skills. In relation to your amendment about a child requiring constant supervision which is substantially greater than that required by a child of the same age who does not have a disability to prevent injury to himself or herself, or to another person or to property, 49 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child had one of the behavioural descriptors in the assessment tool and 34 per cent reported that their child had two of the descriptors.

In regard to your amendment that any other circumstances which in the opinion of the secretary indicates that the child needs substantially more care or attention than a child of the same age who does not have a disability, 31 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child was at least one descriptor behind in receptive communication skills, 30 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child was at least one descriptor behind in expressive communication skills, 30 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child was at least one descriptor behind in social and community skills, and 12 per cent of parents surveyed reported that their child was at least one descriptor behind in mobility skills.

As a result of those findings, it is estimated that, under the proposed amendments that the opposition and the Democrats are bringing forward today, at least 30 per cent of the current child disability allowance population of 120,000 would be eligible for carer payment, and based on CDA experience 50 per cent of them would satisfy the income and assets test. Therefore, the proposed extensions to eligibility would potentially open up the carer payment to an additional 18,000 carers of profoundly disabled children under 16 years of age. Multiplying the expected population by the unit cost of the current meas ure—that is, $1 million divided by 500 recipients—gives an estimate of a total program cost of $36 million. I urge you to think again.

talk.start.para: —I wish to indicate to the Senate that I may have a potential conflict of interest on this particular bill. I say `potential' simply because it will not appear in my pecuniary interest, but I do have a mildly intellectually disabled child. Although he is in receipt of no benefit at this stage, and I am not expecting that he will be, it is possible because of the particular problem that he has that he may in the future be a recipient of extra government assistance at both the state and the federal level. I thought in the interests of making an honest declaration here that I should do so now.

—I wish to add my voice to the debate, because I want to congratulate Senator Newman on the fact that she has introduced this measure to give a benefit to parents of children who are profoundly disabled. It has never been done before. I would hate to see—and I ask that the Democrats listen very carefully to this, and hopefully Senator Harradine is listening—this benefit jeopardised because at the moment we are not able to afford to extend it as far as these amendments before us would try to do. To do what is being done today may jeopardise the benefit flowing to those people who have profoundly disabled children and who have never received a benefit and ought to be recognised by the Australian community as bearing a huge burden. I ask the Democrats and Senator Harradine to very seriously consider whether they are going to support that amendment, which I believe will make the system unworkable and so difficult to administer because you cannot define exactly to whom the benefit ought to go because it gets so broad. I would ask people to think very carefully about that.
—I must say that I just cannot see it as a great tragedy that 16,000 parents of profoundly disabled children will receive a benefit; I would see it as a good thing.

speech.para: I would ask for clarification on an issue I raised in my speech during the second reading debate. Would the minister advise us: under this amendment, how many more people who presently do not receive some other benefit will receive this? You have stated that that greater number of people received this particular payment. But my advice is that many of those people already receive some benefit of some other type, and that the difference it would make would be only about 1,000 people.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Neal forgets that there are fringe benefits that go to people who currently are on a benefit that does not attract them. For example, parents who are on a special benefit are not getting the benefit of a pensioner concession card. As you would know, that card opens up a lot of opportunities for people to reduce their living costs. Also, when two parents are involved in this total care, there is the potential for two carer payments. In addition, the parents, if they do not have to stay on special benefit, no longer have that very onerous requirement of job search requirements and activity testing.

speech.para: In every way it is a great improvement for the families who are applying for this. But we estimate that it would be somewhere between 400 and 500 people who would be eligible.
Question put:
That the requests (Senator Neal's ) be agreed to.

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(4) Schedule 1, item 8, page 6 (after line 1), at the end of the item, add:

para.inline: Qualification when caring for 2 or more children with disabilities

speech.para: (1AB) A person (the carer ) is qualified for carer payment if:
(a) the carer personally provides constant care for 2 or more disabled children; and
Note: See subsections (2 ) and (2AA) below for the circumstances in which this requirement is modified.

The requests for amendment are aimed at those families where none of their disabled children individually satisfies the requirements for a profoundly disabled child. talk.start.para: —We are supporting these requests. We believe that a carer who is looking after two children, even though they may not actually satisfy the criteria individually, obviously has a burden imposed that should be allowed for under this payment. We will be supporting the Democrats.

—I find this whole debate absolutely stunning. For the 13 years that it was in government, Labor did nothing for parents looking after profoundly disabled children, and now they sit here in this hypocritical way extending it to a point where it will be very difficult to be able to afford it. Labor did nothing about it in government and now there is a possibility of jeopardising the whole bill and jeopardising all the other benefits, but also jeopardising the benefits for people with profoundly disabled children. —It does not.

—This adds another $36 million to your promises—spend, spend!—and there will not be money left for anybody, let alone people with profoundly disabled children. I find this debate today very distressing, very disturbing and very sad.
—I must respond to that. If Labor has been behind the mark in extending benefits—
—Thirteen years behind the mark. They did nothing, Bob.

—and in ensuring that people with profoundly disabled children and disabled children were given adequate assistance, I do not think it is going to help the situation to criticise people who want to ensure that assistance is given now.

speech.para: Senator Newman interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would remind Senator Patterson and Senator Newman that we are talking here about $36 million for assistance to people who have more than one disabled child.
—No, sit down. You have missed the point.
—Order! Senator Patterson, Minister.
—The minister was commenting on the previous vote, and now we are going to another vote and an amendment that has been put forward by the Democrats which is being supported by Labor and the Greens.

speech.para: But let us take the last vote and the $36 million that Senator Patterson is concerned about. Just last year this government broke policy to turn around the diesel fuel rebate and give BHP alone $112 million on a silver platter in return of its diesel fuel levy. That does not go to other people who pay the tax. It was BHP—one company. I think that if there was a better look at the distribution of funding by this government, which has repeatedly cut welfare in this country—

talk.start.para: —This is extending it.
—Why don't you read the legislation?

—and advantaged the rich and wealthy, then the members opposite would not be complaining about a further $36 million being given to people in need in this country. Extend the welfare—that is great—but when positive suggestions come forward for a marginal, further extension of that welfare to people in need—and you will not deny that they are in need, Senator Newman—
—I brought it forward!
—Yes, congratulations.
—And now it won't happen because of this.
—Order!

—It only will not happen if Senator Newman's party says, `We're not going to extend this further welfare, this further warranted welfare, this marginal amount of $36 million.' —I had received some requests from the government to try to speed up this debate so that they could get on with their other bits of legislation. I was attempting to cooperate but we have had Senator Patterson getting up and making those sorts of provocative comments. When you tell us that you would like us to speed up the debate and then you spend the time of the chamber attacking the previous government then I do not think that you are very genuine.

speech.para: We have a particular circumstance at the moment with a $2.7 billion surplus and this government—
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators ought to be concerned about the debate but also about more appropriate conduct in this chamber.

—As I said at the beginning of the second reading debate, you have a $2.7 billion surplus cut from low income families and those who are unemployed, old, ill and disabled. You accumulate a $2.7 billion surplus from those people but you say, and Senator Patterson gets up and says, `If we have to spend $36 million on profoundly disabled children then we will reject the whole package.' I find that astonishing.
—It is not finished. You did not get it finished in time.
—If you think that excuse is going to wash out there in the community you have another thing coming, Minister, because I do not believe it will.

speech.para: Requests agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The first Democrat amendment to schedule 3 reads as follows:

speech.para: Schedule 3, item 5, page 33 (lines 9 to 12), to be opposed.

I will speak to the five Democrat amendments; they all address the same topic. As I outlined in my speech in the second reading debate, schedule 3 of the bill deals with the new system of means testing for the various retirement income stream products. The existing system of assessment for allocated pensions and annuities was introduced back in 1994. When that bill was debated, a majority of the Senate voted to exempt those people who had purchased their allocated pensions or annuities prior to 1 July 1992, which was the date of the then government's security and retirement statement on superannuation which included the new means test treatment of those pensions. As such, the pre-1992 treatment of allocated pensions and annuities has applied to these people for many years now. The Democrat amendments Nos 1 through 5 standing in my name are simply designed to maintain that exemption; that is, those people will continue to be treated the way they have been for the past six years or more. I understand that there are only about 1,000 people involved here.

While it does retain a bit of an anomaly, if you like, and different people will come out ahead or behind in relation to the new treatment for pre-1992 people, the basic principle that was applied when the Senate originally considered this back in 1994 of people having a consistent understanding of how their pensions, annuities or retirement incomes are arranged is an important one and where possible we should seek to maintain the way that people's income arrangements are treated.

talk.start.para: —There are some remarks I do want to make about this because this measure will impact significantly on an unknown number of people—I would like the minister to give me a best estimate. I certainly believe that thousands of retirees will be classified as self-funded retirees on a part pension. The effect of it is retrospective. I have two letters from people who are retired: one person is aged 71 and the other, the President of Australian Pensioners League, is in his 80s. The difficulty with this measure is that it forces people to unravel their retirement income stream purchases. I would like to know the number who will be required to unravel. Secondly, Minister, could you give us a precise estimate of the savings the government believes will result from this measure?

speech.para: Minister, I also draw your attention to an answer you gave last week in respect of self-funded retirees. You were stressing in the answer to that question that, in respect of the health card issue, self-funded retirees who had struggled and saved and put money aside during their working lives to encourage thrift were being rewarded for that. Here we have a similar category of people in their retirement years—the people who have contacted me are in their 70s and 80s—who are being forced to unravel long-term retirement income contracts by the changes you are imposing.

The two particular concerns are, firstly, there is a cost to unravelling agreed legal documents in respect of the purchase of income stream products. I understand it may be $1,000 or $2,000, depending on the type of contractual agreement that is being entered into.

Secondly, why should people who were given an assurance in 1992—admittedly, you could say by the former Labor government—about the long-term nature of a retirement income product now be required to unravel those arrangements in their retirement years? These are people who have been thrifty and who have saved—people that you, Minister, have acknowledged have been very responsible. This certainly has caused considerable outrage amongst a sector of the retirement community.

Very briefly, because we are under time constraints, I want to put on the record some correspondence from a Mr Sydney Horne. He maintains that the government's `new broom' approach, which is supposed to sweep away all so-called anomalies, is fanciful. He said:
The stated aims of the government are to encourage private saving to ensure that superannuation and other savings are directed towards providing retirement income.

But the reality for Mr Horne is that he will have to unravel his retirement product, his retirement arrangements. It is effectively a retrospective unravelling. I understand Mr Horne wrote to you, Minister. He has forwarded to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation copies of the correspondence. He was not very impressed with the response. He maintains, and I certainly agree with him, that the effect of this is retrospective. It will affect aged pensioners. He believes that in his case he will lose one-third of his income from a product that he purchased eight years ago. You can understand people's concern—particularly a person who is aged, retired and has done the right thing—that they will lose one-third of their income and will have to seek financial advice at a cost. This reminds me somewhat of the issues we debated last year with the deeming of superannuation when a person reaches age 55. Harsh outcomes have been the result of that government measure.

I know we are under a time constraint, and I very much regret that because this is a change that will, I believe, adversely affect many thousands of retirees. They will have a great deal of worry and concern imposed on them by what I believe is a very harsh and unjust measure.

talk.start.para: —I hope you don't join your colleagues and undertake a scaremongering campaign.
—When he knows the facts he won't.

—I will take those interjections. There is no need to start a scare campaign in respect of the deeming of superannuation for people who hit 55 because we have had a significant number of representations from those individuals, and they are deeply aggrieved. As evidenced by the correspondence I have received on this matter, there will be a significant number of individuals. We will not need to run a scare campaign about it all. They are very scared as a result of what your government is attempting to do.

speech.para: There is one last question I would like to ask the minister. On page 21 of the 1997 budget statement `Savings: choice and incentive', it says:

Individuals who have products purchased before this budget will be able to request an exemption from the new rules when they have a contract that cannot be broken or where significant penalties would apply for changing the current contract.

I have made some comments about contractual arrangements. Thirdly, Minister, could you please tell me what you regard as a `significant penalty' in financial terms? Is it $500, $1,000 or $2,000? Requests will come to you as minister from people who want to change their contractual arrangements.

talk.start.para: —I am intrigued that Senator Sherry should come in here and purport to discuss this measure in those terms. The opposition was very thoroughly briefed on this measure. I understood that they were supportive of it. I certainly know that this measure was not introduced lightly before there had been long consultation with the retirement industry and with retirees. I also understand that there is considerable support for this measure because of the need to make this a clearer area. There needs to be a more logical basis on which people can assess how they will be affected by social security depending on the product—not the sort of dog's breakfast that we have had.

speech.para: I will get to some hard facts, Senator, because obviously you were not briefed. But Ms Macklin, the spokesperson, was briefed. This is what the impact of the changes is estimated to be in the first year. This is, of course, the crucial year, because it is the year that affects people who are already in these forms of income stream. It affects these people more than it affects people who will come on board in years to come.

In the first year, 40,200 customers will receive a pension increase, 16,000 customers will have their rate of pension reduced if they do not take other action, and 2,100 customers will have their pensions cancelled. But 270,000 customers with income stream products will not be affected by the proposal—mostly those with defined benefit income streams. Customers most likely to be adversely affected by the new rules are those who are using loopholes, such as those people with fixed term superannuation pensions. Most will now have their investment included in the assets test, whereas currently all these products are assets test exempt. Those with annuities with terms of five years or less will now be subject to deeming rules and they will no longer receive the benefit of a full year's reduction in asset value at the commencement of their term.

There are also very strong arguments against allowing a saving provision for these products because, given that allocated pensions can be commuted at any time, a person could adjust their investments and take out an income stream that is assets test exempt. Some of the main beneficiaries of savings provisions would be people who could either fully or partly provide for themselves in retirement but who are taking advantage of a loophole which allows an assets test exemption to access an age pension or a higher rate of payment.

While some may lose their asset test exemption, the income test treatment of allocated pensions will be more generous than under current arrangements, given the use of purchase price as the deduction. If they are subject to a saving provision, this group of people will miss out on the more generous income test. The depleted asset value, as at 20 September 1998, will be used for calculating the impact of the assets test and, given that these products will have been operating for at least six years, the assets value will be substantially depleted in most cases. The assets test may, in fact, have no impact on them given the depleted asset value.

Importantly, the ministerial exemption power is available to assist those people who are financially disadvantaged by the new arrangements and who cannot rearrange their affairs without a significant penalty. That is not something new: there are certain circumstances in the social security legislation—a very restricted range of areas, I admit—where the minister does have an exemption power. This would be one of them. Where people could not rearrange their affairs without facing a significant penalty I would be committed to assisting them. But it would be difficult to justify saving provisions which are isolated to those products. It could generate a call for arrangements in place before 20 September this year to be saved.

Administratively, the saving provisions would also be very complicated, I am advised. Revised running costs would have to be sought to enable Centrelink to run parallel systems to administer both the current and the new means testing arrangements. So I do suggest to Senator Bartlett that there is a better way of achieving what he would like to achieve through his amendment to save the pre-1992 people. I trust that Senator Sherry is now somewhat better informed than perhaps he was.

talk.start.para: —Thanks for the offensive—
—Gratuitous remarks.
—slings and gratuitous remarks, Minister. We are attempting to facilitate this bill.
—I was being helpful.

—Well, you have not helped me on two other issues, and I will get to that in a moment. I understand we will be supporting the measure but it is a very difficult measure to support, given that you are playing off the fact that 40,200 people get an increase and—you have acknowledged this for the record and for the purposes of this debate—16,000 people will have their retirement incomes reduced. I am pleased you have acknowledged that for the record.

speech.para: We have to be concerned about these 16,000 people because they will have a reduction in their income, having entered in good faith into an income stream product purchase that they believed would continue until the day they died. These people now in their 60s, 70s and 80s are in a very difficult situation. The questions I have raised are because of the specific correspondence I have had in relation to this matter. I quoted from page 21 of the budget paper which talks about their having a contract that cannot be broken or where significant penalties would apply for changing the current contract. What is a significant penalty in monetary terms? How will you make that judgment?

talk.start.para: —I just want to respond to some matters that were mentioned by the minister in her gratuitous insults earlier. She seemed to be implying that, in one case, the opposition indicated support then there was some change of position. I stated in the second reading debate, and our position is unchanged, that we are supportive of the general thrust of these overall changes in taking account of income streams. But that does not necessarily mean that we are not amenable to the needs of a small group of people, the pre-1992 people, who had allocated pensions and annuities. First, it is relatively defined and small group. Secondly, when it was agreed at the time in 1992 to exempt that group of people, there was general agreement, I am advised, from all parties including us while we were in government and, I believe the coalition—the present government. Maybe the minister would like to enlighten us on that. You mentioned a number of figures, Minister. As I understand it, they relate to the whole raft of changes. We would be very interested to know the cost of the amendment before us now that was moved by the Democrats, not the amount of money involved in the entire schedule.

speech.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —I table four supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to government amendments and requests to be moved to the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Bill 1998 and six related bills. These memoranda were circulated in the chamber on 26 May last. I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 56, page 32 (line 7), omit "powers", substitute "functions".

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in the committee stage of this bill, which is one of the most far-reaching bills to ever be put before the parliament dealing with the financial system. By dint of those far-reaching powers, it has major ramifications at a national, international and regional level.

speech.para: I would first like to start by finding out from the government how it plans to counter the likely impact of some of the measures in this package, particularly the question of banks and consolidation. Small towns in particular in regional Australia are losing their banking services. This is coming on top of losing their Medicare offices and CES offices, albeit supposedly replaced by this new and better service which we have seen on advertisements on the television. Despite this new and better service, my colleague, Senator West, has asked question this week about office closures, lack of access and all the impacts that are currently being felt in the regional centres. Telstra offices and railway stations have closed in regional centres and now there are the government's plans for Australia Post. Regional Australia is getting a raw deal out of this government. Once this bill is agreed to and passed by the Senate almost certainly regional banking operations will be taken away.

This bill needs to address that and I am hoping the government can quieten fears of the people of regional Australia about the impact of this bill. It will allow big banks which are making huge profits to close down their banking services, introduce more ATMs and reduce personalised services and access to the banking services that regional Australia needs.

In today's Herald Sun there are examples of women in particular being robbed at ATMs. It happens in the city all the time but, as there are fewer opportunities for access to banking services in country centres, one can expect to see the same sorts of problems compounding. Those are the real world impacts on ordinary Australians in regional centres; not airy-fairy impacts such as better competition or impacts on the global market and international financing.

The government has an opportunity today to tell us how this measure of reforms, as it calls them, will address that issue. I hope that that will be part of the discussion today with Senator Ian Campbell and that he can reassure us that regional Australia will not suffer just because the government has a cosy deal going with the banks and the Wallis group. Also, just because the Wallis committee said that there are a lot of economic efficiency gains to be made by these proposals, I hope that the government is not wedded to this `free market at all costs' approach and has no role to play.

I hope we are in a position where Senator Ian Campbell and the government will explain the benefits to us and how regional Australia will benefit from losing its banking services. As I said, it has already lost its Medicare offices, CES offices and its Telstra centres, and the loss of its post offices is to come. I hope that the government is in a position to explain that to the Senate.

I was lucky enough last week to be at a speech given by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank. He talked about his concerns about the trend towards self-regulation and away from what can be called black-letter regulation—that is, parliamentary legislation, to the laissez faire approach. He cited a number of examples around the world where countries have given up sovereignty and the capacity to influence their own economies by opening up without question to the world financiers.

This package of bills is in that vein. It is about self-regulation rather than black-letter regulation. It is about allowing flows in and out. It talks about foreign ownership and how foreigners can come in and buy our banks. Banks are very important strategic national institutions. They have a very important role to play in making sure that we control our own destiny, that we are not captive to interests in the US, or interests in Japan, or interests in Europe. Wallis is gung-ho, open slather, throw open the doors, let's have everybody in, irrespective of the consequences.

Last week, Dr Neville, Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, ran up a bit of a flag to say, `Well, just a minute. There are consequences in allowing that sort of untrammelled access.' He talked about the impact that the untrammelled flows have had in Asia. That is a large part of what has gone on. He was very concerned about the number of capital movements that are short-term, not long-term productive investment—just in, a bit of speculation and out. He was flagging that the Reserve Bank of Australia believes that an untrammelled throw-open-the-gates approach is the wrong one. That is the view of the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank. And yet this government seems hell-bent on running down that path.

Today is the opportunity for Senator Campbell to tell the Australian people, the Senate, and those in the gallery how this package is going to protect Australians, protect Australia's sovereignty. That is the challenge of the debate in the chamber today: how we are able to see more greatly enhanced national sovereignty and individual protection arising out of this bill.
The government have just dropped some amendments on us in the last 24 hours—

talk.start.para: —Few minutes.

—In the last few minutes, as Senator Bolkus correctly says. One of them in particular is of concern to me. It is the desire to take away consumer protection from the ACCC. I would have to argue, as others have recently, that the ACCC and Professor Fels have run amok. They have been happy to talk about market monopolies on the supply side, but they have not been prepared to talk about market monopolies on the business side. I think there is a legitimate criticism of the unevenness of the approach of the ACCC.

speech.para: Notwithstanding that criticism, the ACCC is a body that has had many successes in making sure consumers are protected. In the transport industry in which I used to work, the ACCC caught a number of the major transport companies colluding to make sure that prices of courier services were kept high. It was a simple little scam based on an informal agreement. When you phoned one of the major companies in an area that as part of that agreement belonged to the other company they would quote you a deliberately exorbitant amount. You would then check with the company that had been informally designated and they would give you a realistic price—although slightly above what would be a competitive price. The ACCC caught them and fined them $20 million-odd dollars. That is the sort of success the ACCC has had.

What we see today is attempts to take the regulation of consumer protection in financial services out of the control of the ACCC and pass it to the new ASIC. It has a massive number in responsibilities. The opposition is supporting the creation of ASIC. We think it is a step forward, but only if it is given the resources to deal with the issues. That is my third biggest concern with this legislation.

This government is not fair dinkum about consumer protection in financial services, because it is passing them across to a body which is underfunded—not just slightly but massively underfunded. At the same time, it is trying to foist the MIB on ASIC—that is not `men in black', as some people may know it, but the Managed Investments Bill 1997 —which is a significant shift in corporate practice in this country. It is passing regula tions and laws to heap much more onto ASIC's areas of responsibility and not giving it enough funds. The government is not giving it enough funds just to cope with the MIB legislation, never mind the extra regulation that it is now getting because of lumping consumer protection in with financial services.

The government is wiping out the ISC and moving its responsibilities. The ISC has had a chequered history. It has not been perfect; it has been criticised. I have had some dealings with it over time in my previous occupation as a superannuation officer, but it was always running on the smell of an oily rag. And we are seeing too many things being put under the jurisdiction of ASIC and the government not prepared to prove how fair dinkum it is by giving it significant funding.

I hope the government will stand up today and argue that it has given ASIC $7 million to deal with MIB and it will be adequately budgeted for. I am hoping Senator Campbell can reassure the chamber about this. I am hoping he can take us through exactly how much extra money ASIC is going to have to cope with these extra responsibilities that are flowing to it by the passage of this bill, by the possible passage of the MIB. I am looking forward to that contribution from Senator Campbell.

In closing, I make a couple of points which, at this stage, the government seems to be supporting and which I really want to stress the opposition's position on—that is, the issue of dealing with the foreign takeovers and, more importantly, what is known as the big four, the banks. We will not support mergers between the big banks being allowed. There are already exorbitant profits being made in the banking sector at the expense of ordinary Australians. There is no way this opposition will support legislation that in any way sees a reduction in the limited competition that is there now.

The banks are making huge profits, billions of dollars a year, all at the expense of ordinary Australians. I am sure you have all seen the extra charges. When you open your bank statement, there is charge after charge running down the sheet. That has all come about in the last few years as the banks have sought to repair their balance sheets for their poor lending practices in the 1980s and early 1990s when they had to write off millions and millions of dollars worth of bad loans that they made. No-one forced them to make them; they just tossed the money around.

The banks have had to recoup that money by going to their loyal customers who stuck with them through thick and thin. Often they were customers with small accounts. The banks have been slugging the ordinary pensioners and battlers they were always claiming to protect. We now see the banks ripping off those battlers. The banks are saying they have no social role and that they do not have to subsidise the poor because that is not their job. That is fair enough. If that is their position, at least they are honest enough to say it before parliamentary committees and to say in the papers that they are not responsible. But, if the banks are not responsible, then who is? This parliament is. That is why we have to be very careful with this legislation.

As I said, Senator Campbell, here is an opportunity to reassure Australians and to reassure everybody who is listening today that these reforms will benefit. I will be listening, and lots of Australians will be listening when you speak. We are hoping to be reassured on these issues.

talk.start.para: —I am reassured that Senator Conroy thinks that all Australians will be listening when I speak. Maybe my mum will be. Hi mum.
—Have you got one of them?

—A very nice one, thank you very much. Madam Chairman, Senator Conroy does raise some very important questions. I think a very legitimate debate is occurring throughout the community about what is happening to banking and financial services delivery in Australia. As all senators know, that flowed from the implementation of the recommendations following Sir Keith Campbell's committee of inquiry. Those recommendations were put in place by then Treasurer Keating in his early years. We saw the Australian financial system opened up and the entry of foreign banks. Those changes did cause concerns.

speech.para: Clearly, the mergers of major banks that have occurred over the past few years have caused concern. The closure of banks and restricted access to banking services in regional Australia has caused concern. I know in remote areas of Western Australia—as Senator Peter Cook knows well—when you go out to the goldfields they actually have cash flow crises because there is no money in these towns. You cannot go to the pub and cash a cheque in Leonora because there is no money. There are very serious problems.

We believe, and I understand the Labor Party share our hope, that these reforms will assist in alleviating those problems. They will do so, we hope—and we can only hope as we try to make the law the best possible facilitator to create change—in a number of ways. You have asked very serious questions on these things, and we hope that the passage of this legislation and the bringing in of the new scheme—which we hope can occur on 1 July, if parliament can pass these bills today—will see changes.

One of the most important changes that I personally believe will take place is, indeed, the bringing in of a regulatory system that brings all deposit taking institutions under a similar regulatory regime. We have already seen indications through reforms that this government has put in place, such as the cheque and payment orders bill, which allow building societies and credit unions, for the first time in Australian history, to issue cheques on their own account and not have to go through the expensive routine of issuing them on behalf of another bank. So they are able to provide services to small business at a lower cost than they have ever been able to do before.

In many parts of Australia, we have seen credit unions, the credit care movement, building societies and other financial institutions moving in to take up the slack left by the big banks in regional areas. That is something that we encourage.

Most Australians have seen the massive influx of Aussie Home Loans and all of these mortgage originators into the home loan market. They are really giving the big banks massive competition. Not only because of the general movement down in interest rates but also because of massive increases in competition, that is seen as a significant reduction which is to the benefit of most Australians in terms of home lending.

We have seen some of that flow through into business lending, but not enough yet. The coalition, and I am sure all parties, would love to see more competition in the small business lending sector. I know it is a sector that is close to Senator Murray's heart. We want to see the banks really challenged by originators, credit unions and building societies in the creation of new products for small businesses and in the driving down of the costs of those financial products.

They are all things that we think can flow naturally from the so-called Wallis reforms. They are the sorts of benefits that I think Senator Conroy has in mind. I do not think there is any division between the parties on the desirability of that being achieved. That is certainly the intent.

In relation to the second tranche of matters raised by Senator Conroy, again, these are very important issues. They relate to international capital flows and the foreign ownership and control of Australian banks. I referred yesterday in my second reading speech to the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in relation to the four major banks. We have made it the government's policy that the four banks will not be allowed to merge, and we will keep a close eye on competition to the major banks. That remains our policy, and I appreciate the opposition's support for that.

We also believe that foreign control is a very important aspect of these major institutions. I incorporated in Hansard the whole of the Treasurer's press release dated 9 April in that regard. It outlines the government's policy in relation to foreign ownership and control of banks, and the mergers of banks. As Senator Conroy asked me to do, I refer any Australian who is interested to the Hansard at page 3091 of 28 May for a statement of government policy.

Before addressing the other issue that Senator Conroy raises, I say that I do genu inely appreciate his interest in this subject. I know that when I first joined the Senate I got myself onto the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which he is now an active member of. It is not what one would call a sexy area of public policy—

talk.start.para: —It depends what turns you on.

—That is right. There are people who do get turned on by this, Senator Murray. If I was organising a quiet, romantic night at home with my wife, I do not think I would pull out a copy of the Corporations Law and read it to her to get her amorous. It is not the sort of natural area where you might focus if you are trying to make your political career jump. You get page 3 of the business pages, if you are lucky, on corporate law matters. But Senator Conroy has taken a genuine interest in these areas and is one of the active members who has taken a big interest in the Wallis reforms, the managed investments bill and the company law reform process which is being busily run by this government, and was very actively pursued, I might say, by former Attorney-General Lavarch under the previous government. So there is a lot of work going on there. It is not, as I said, exciting work but, if it is done properly, it can make big changes to Australia, though they will probably not go particularly recognised. Senator Conroy does have an interest there.

speech.para: The funding of the regulator is a very important issue. This has been a concern raised by a number of senators. It has been raised by the consumers association, by corporate governance watchdog organisations and by the business community generally. We want to have a well-funded ASIC; we want to have a well-funded regulator that does its job well. The ASC, under the chairmanship of Alan Cameron, is to be commended for the reforms it has made as part of the ASC 2000 process. It has brought in a lot of efficiencies to its back office tasks. For example, it has saved about 15 per cent by consolidating its property, amalgamating a number of offices and so on forth. It has saved a lot of money.

The government treats the funding of the regulator very seriously. We have in this budget announced a $50 million package for the next four years, which is a straight-up boost. We have announced a further $7 million for the two-year transitional period for the managed investment scheme. I have already given the opposition a written assurance—which I repeat here for the record—on the monitoring of the funding needs in relation to both managed investments and the shifting of the new responsibilities under the Wallis proposals to ASIC. We will be continually monitoring the appropriateness of funding for the new ASIC. On top of the $50 million over four years, there is the $7 million special package for the transitional phase of MIB. We have also shifted all of the funding that existed for that section of the operations of ISC that are moving as a consequence of this across to ASIC. All of the funding goes with all of those roles and all of those people.

We believe that is a responsible funding package. It is in the government's interest to fund ASIC well in these matters. It is in the government's interest, it is in our crass, pragmatic political interest, to make sure that ASIC performs very well. As chairman of the Ministerial Council on Corporations, I would get crucified by my state colleagues, the state Attorneys-General, distinguished members such as Geoff Shaw from New South Wales, if quality of service deteriorates in any of the service centres provided by the ASC, as it is now, and ASIC, as it will become known as a result of the passage of these bills. There is a very active feedback mechanism in relation to services provided by the ASC.

The West Australian business community, as Senator Peter Cook knows well, monitor this very well. They fought the foundation of the ASC, as Senator Peter Cook would well know, because they were very worried about funding and service reductions in the regions. As a West Australian senator, I am ever vigilant about ensuring that the service quality remains in the state capitals. I assure the Senate, all Australians and Senator Conroy in particular that if the funding for ASIC creates any service difficulties or regulatory difficulties I will probably be the first person in this country, this great wide land, that will know about it. I hope that answers the legitimate concerns that you raise.

talk.start.para: —Thank you for that, Senator Campbell. I am sure that that has reassured some people about the concerns that I raised. I would have to concur with you that when I go home in the evening and talk to my partner and she asks me what I was doing for the day, chatting about CLERP and ASIC and MIB is certainly a quick—
—Change the subject.

—That is right. I have one quick question which you may be able to get answered by the officials or may like to take on notice, in reference to RAMS and the mortgage originators. Is there any information available, either handy or on notice, about the number of originator mortgages in regional areas in particular? I am dealing here with what can be broadly referred to as the Patrick amendments. They arise with some urgency because of the requirement that our financial sector, our business sector and, indeed, our employee sector be protected from practices which would otherwise be very dangerous if they were allowed to continue.

You will note that item 1 provides a date by which this is to have commenced, and it refers to the date 3 May. I have followed the practice of the government and of the former Labor government of relating the amendment back to the date of a press release, in case of companies taking advantage of the situation between knowing of such an amendment coming up and the amendment becoming law to exercise what I may refer to as devious practices. That is the significance of the date 3 May 1998.

The substantive amendment is that on item 2, and it refers to the liability for debts or liabilities of a related body corporate. We are concerned here with entities structuring themselves in such a way as to avoid liabilities or responsibilities by interposing companies with little capital backing between creditors, employees and the companies within the group which have substantial assets.

This is not a new problem. In 1988 the Law Reform Commission conducted a general insolvency inquiry. As a part of that inquiry, the commission considered the possibility of making related companies liable for the debts of an insolvent company in certain circumstances, and the commission recommended that companies should be so liable. A draft section D13 was produced. That draft section is a relatively simple one which essentially hands a discretion to a court to order a related company to contribute an amount to the debts of the insolvent company on its winding up.

In its considerations the Law Reform Commission—and for the purposes of Hansard, I am referring to pages 146 and 147 of that report—reported as will follow. I ask for the Senate to bear with me, because I think what they said is worth repeating at length so I will quote all the way through. The quote is as follows:

para.inline: Liability for debts or liabilities of a related company

speech.para: 334. Relaxation of separate entity principle . Although this topic of liability for debts or liabilities of related companies does not strictly fall under the heading of director liability and disqualification, it is similar in that it deals with the imposition of liability on persons who have been closely connected with the running of the company but who would ordinarily be protected from being required to contribute to the amount available for distribution in the winding up. Under the existing law, the separate personality of each company prevents access to the funds of one company for the payment of the debts or liabilities of a related company except where the debtor company is a shareholder or creditor of the related company. This may operate unfairly where the business activity of a company has been directed or controlled by a related company. It is as though the related company was acting as a `director' of the other company and causing it to incur debts and liabilities.

335. Proposal in DP 32 . In DP 32 (para 222) the Commission proposed to give the court a wide discretion to order that a company that is or has been a related company pay to the liquidator all or part of an amount which is an admissible claim in the winding up `if it is satisfied that it is just'. Three specific criteria to which it was proposed the court may have regard were
. the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the company
. the conduct of the related company towards the creditors of the company and
. the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the company are attributable to the actions of the related company.
It should not, of course, be sufficient that creditors have merely relied on the assets of the related company in their decision to deal with the company.
336. Assessment and recommendation. The Commission's proposal was supported by several submissions. One submission, from the Law Council of Australia, strongly opposed the proposal on four grounds.

. Separate entity principle. The Council said that it is a fundamental principle of company law that separate companies have separate legal entities. However, as a matter of policy, the Commission sees no reasonable objection to recommending the imposition of liability where a parent company permits its subsidiary to incur debts when insolvent.

. Project financing. The Council argued that financing for large resource and other projects needs to be done on a limited recourse basis, but that, under the Commission's proposal, it would not be possible for a parent company to satisfy itself that it would not be liable for the debts of the project. However, the fact that creditors have entered into contracts on a limited recourse basis would be one of the `other relevant matters' to which the court is required to have regard.

. Uncertainty. The Council said that the uncertainty in commercial dealings that would be created by the wide discretion given to the court would be undesirable. Lenders would be unable to ascertain the true liabilities of parent companies and could be expected to assume that at least some unguaranteed liabilities of subsidiaries should be taken into account. However, persons lending to the parent of a group of companies have regard not only to its balance sheet but to the consolidated balance sheet of the group and generally take cross-collateralised security. The Commission does not accept therefore that the suggested uncertainty would follow from its proposal. Moreover liability for a subsidiary's debts otherwise than under a guarantee would only arise in the context of the Commission's recommendations where that subsidiary was or became insolvent.

. Accounts. The Council suggested that auditors and company directors would have enormous difficulty in producing accounts which represent a true and fair view of a parent company. However, the Commission does not accept that accounting difficulties are sufficiently serious to deter it from recommending the imposition of liability on a parent company which has permitted its subsidiary to trade while insolvent.
Accordingly, the Commission recommends that companies be liable for the debts or liabilities of related companies in the manner set out in D13.

I have quoted at length to make sure that it is clear in the Hansard what the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission were. It went on in fact to outline, in what it refers as section D13, the way in which this section should be structured. I have stuck as faithfully as I can to the section that the Law Reform Commission laid out, partly because there is no sense in reinventing the wheel but also because it had obviously carefully considered the matters and weighed the manner in which it should be presented.

I say `as carefully as I can' because I have had to add one section. That is the section which is item 2(d) on sheet 1006. That arose because of the following. Senators would be aware that this occurrence has occurred in three specific instances recently in relation to employee entitlements and that is what is known as the Woodlawn, the Cobar and the Patrick examples. Of course the attention, quite rightly, has been focused on the awful consequences of employers evading their responsibilities through structuring their affairs in such a way that they can escape them.

While it is true that the Woodlawn, the Cobar and the Patrick examples all relate to employee entitlements, proposed section 588YA will inure for the benefit of all creditors, including those who have judgment debts against the insolvent company as a result of proceedings taken under sections 51AA, 51AB or 51AC of the Trade Practices Act or the franchising code of conduct or any other of the state based retail tenancy legislation for that matter.

Now you are pricking up your ears and you are saying, `Now he's referring to creditors and, not only is he referring to creditors, he is actually referring to matters that affect small business.' I was alerted to this by a letter I got from an organisation which indicated the real danger. I will quote from that letter but I do not choose to give you the source. The letter said:
I consider that your proposed amendments—
because I had circulated these, as I told you, on 3 May—

may also have a wider application to the recent fair trading package in that franchises and shopping centre owners could establish corporate shells to run various business enterprises. Should a franchisee or a retail tenant in a shopping centre ultimately be successful in court proceedings against a business enterprise concerning unconscionable conduct, an award for damages may not be effective if the entity has no assets or puts itself into voluntary administration. The establishment of such corporate structures would, of course, defeat the fair trading reforms.

Those are important points because, regardless of what your political perspective is, I would be surprised if any senator in any political party would actually relish the thought of companies being able to avoid their obligations to suppliers, banks, landlords, tenants and customers as well as to employees through the restructuring and the deliberate manipulation of their corporate structure to avoid their obligations. I think this kind of legal and accounting spivery should be stamped on by the parliament. It should be stamped on so forcefully that these people will realise that we will not put up with what is immoral and should be illegal.

I do not know why, and I have not inquired into the reasons why, that particular Law Reform Commission recommendation is not yet in law, but I do think it is time we redressed that problem. I would seek, because I do regard it as an urgent matter, the urgent support and the full support of the Senate in stamping this out. It has much reference to recent events, but it really is part of a far broader problem and a far bigger picture. I therefore commend these two amendments to the Senate.
